bestBHT.bht: The apostle Paul ironically criticizes the Corinthians for taking their trivial disputes to the unbelieving judges. In his scathing tone, Paul questions their choice and suggests that even the least esteemed members of the church would be better qualified to judge such matters. By involving pagan magistrates, the Corinthians not only overlook the insignificance of earthly property disputes but also underestimate the role of Christians as judges over the world and angels. It is clear that Paul disapproves of Christians seeking worldly judgments rather than resolving conflicts within the church.

Henry Alford: The description of these secular causes is emphatically repeated as being the only sort of judgments which were in question here.
Your office is to judge angels' mere business causes of this world are almost beneath your notice.
Let it be noticed that he is passing to ver. 7, where he insists on the impropriety of judgments in this life's matters between Christians at all, and is here depreciating them ironically.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Any, however low in the Church, rather than the heathen.
Questions of earthly property are of secondary consequence in the eyes of true Christians.
Delegated to those in a secondary position in the Church.
Albert Barnes: Do ye set or appoint them to judge who are of little repute for their wisdom and equity?
Since you are abundantly qualified yourselves to settle your own differences, do you employ the pagan magistrates, in whom the church can have little confidence for their integrity and justice?

The pagan magistrates were in general very corrupt, there can be no doubt. Many of them were people of abandoned character, of dissipated lives, men who were easily bribed, and people, therefore, in whose judgment Christians could repose little confidence.
Marvin Vincent: Dare they, the destined judges of the world and of angels, go to law about mere earthly trifles, and that before the heathen?"
Why did they not rather set up the very humblest members of the Church to act as judges in such matters?
John Calvin: Even the lowest and meanest among you will discharge this office better than those unbelieving judges to whom you have recourse. So far are you from necessity in this way.
The lowest among believers was preferred by him to unbelievers, as to the capacity of judging.

That ancient custom there are two things that are deserving of reproof — that the bishops were involved in matters that were foreign to their office; and that they wronged God in making his authority and command a pretext for turning aside from their proper calling.
Philip Schaff: If then ye have to judge things pertaining to this life, set them to judge who are of no account in the church.
An ironical way of hinting that their differences were so petty that the poorest-witted among them were fit enough to deal with them.
To view this as a question 'Do ye set, etc.?' as some do, seems to us very unnatural.
Archibald T. Robertson: If ye have tribunals pertaining to this life
Who are of no account in the church
It is a harsh term for the heathen, but one of indignation toward Christians.
John Gill: Not judgements relating to life and death, for these were not in the power of a Jewish sanhedrim now, and much less of a Christian community, but were wholly in the power of the Roman magistrates; but judgments relating to the common affairs of life...

But private persons, laymen, [the apostle] would rather choose out from among the laity persons of the best judgment and capacity, to be umpires and arbitrators in such worldly matters, which do not so properly come under the notice and cognizance of spiritual guides.
And these are the men the apostle means, at least alludes to, before whom he would have the causes brought.
John Wesley: Them who are of no esteem in the church — That is, heathens, who, as such, could be in no esteem with the Christians.

bhtAttempts.bht: The apostle Paul is admonishing the Corinthians to not bring their disputes and judgments about earthly matters before unbelieving judges. He emphasizes that these secular concerns are insignificant in comparison to the higher calling of Christians and the future judgment they will have over the world and angels. The Corinthians should have been wise enough to appoint even the lowliest members of the church to arbitrate their trivial disputes, rather than involve pagan magistrates who were known for their corruption and lack of integrity. Paul's irony and indignation demonstrate his disapproval of Christians seeking worldly judgments instead of resolving issues amongst themselves.

Paul urges the Corinthians to refrain from bringing their earthly disputes before pagan judges, as these matters are insignificant in light of their future role as judges over the world and angels. He sarcastically questions their decision to involve unbelievers in such trivial matters, suggesting that even the lowest esteemed members of the church would be more suitable judges. By prioritizing earthly concerns over spiritual matters, the Corinthians undermine the integrity of the church and miss out on the opportunity to resolve conflicts amongst themselves.
